spans.text: Night was slowly painting the sky, and the slightly hurried footsteps had already disappeared from the edge of the unfinished commercial district that was being redeveloped. The longing for a hot bath and a bed made the already short distance seem even shorter, and Taki Shiina quickly walked towards home.
It's almost there after the small park.
This fact put her at ease a little. The evening twilight was gradually fading, and it was just dark enough now, but the streetlights on both sides of the road hadn't come on yet.
(If the hours before dusk are the witching hour for ghosts and gods, then this time period must be the witching hour for weirdos.)

She looked at the scenery along the road with some wariness. Although she had left the unfinished commercial district where the homeless lived, the nearly abandoned park was not a suitable place to walk through at night either.
Naturally, the incident a few days ago when she encountered the police investigating a case in front of her house came to mind again.

Because she had to make sure that the children were picked up by their parents, her time leaving work was later than that of ordinary people. By the time she rushed all the way back to her doorstep, it was mostly after dusk.

Each household had already eaten dinner, those who were resting were resting, and those who had gone out for a walk to digest their food had already left. Usually, there were no people in sight by the roadside, but today was different.
(Is that... a police officer standing under the streetlight?)
(What are they doing here at this time?)
(...I'll just go around them.)
Excuse me, miss, please wait a moment.
The police officer wearing a black raincoat was tall and large, almost blocking the light scattered by the streetlights.
Are you a resident of this area?
Uh, yes.
Were you at home around eight o'clock last night?
I was...
Did you notice anything unusual happening outside at that time?
(Last night, I was sitting at my desk preparing lesson plans, looping "Hito ni wa Sorezore Jijou ga Aru" by Masatoshi Mashima all night.)
Sorry, I was wearing headphones at the time and didn't know anything about what was happening outside.
I see...
Did something happen?
There have been attacks in this area recently.
Is the victim... okay?
The police officer made way for Taki.
They only suffered injuries to their hands. But hearing that they are in a performing profession, it's hard to say it was fortunate.
(A performing profession? It can't be that coincidental.)
As if wanting to reassure the uneasy citizen, the police officer began to talk about their remedial measures.
In short, we will strengthen patrols in this area recently, and the installation of surveillance cameras on various roads is also on the agenda...
Hiss, the rain is getting heavier.
Life is truly unpredictable... but we will do our best to protect the safety of residents. Thank you for your cooperation, please go home now.
His ending sentence had a firm upward inflection, but Taki sighed for no reason, turned around, and dragged her weary steps toward home.
Life is unpredictable... huh?

No one likes the fragility contained in this phrase, "life will be messed up by sudden unexpected events," just as no one expects a drunkard who attacks people to suddenly jump out of the roadside bushes.

Her consciousness drifted back to reality, and she had already walked to the entrance of the small park while thinking about this. The shadows of the trees flickered, and the roadside bushes, having lost their pruning, grew wildly, thickly and disorderly taller than a person's waist, enough for an adult to crouch and hide behind them.
The pitch-black and unknown environment breeds imagination, but fortunately, as the road turned, a bright beam of flashlight appeared in the bushes.
(The person holding the flashlight doesn't seem to have noticed me yet. If I turn around and run now...)

She was almost about to turn around and leave, but the other person seemed to have finally found what they were looking for. The flashlight beam momentarily shone from the treetops to the ground, and the briefly appearing familiar hair color made her stop again.
Doubt and untimely curiosity took over, and Taki had no intention of running away this time. As she got closer, the scarf that appeared dark green in the shadows further strengthened her judgment.
Tomori!

The one whose name was called turned her attention and the direction of the flashlight towards her. The sudden brightness made Taki subconsciously raise her hand to cover her eyes. It was also in this moment of blankness that the question she wanted to ask was spoken by the other person first.
Taki...? What are you doing here?
I got off work a little late today, so I'm taking a shortcut through here.
But Tomori, why are you coming to such a dangerous place alone at this time? Recently, this area has been...
Something happened in this area, it's not very safe. If you're coming, you should at least tell me first, and I can come with you.
She hesitated for a moment, not going into further detail about the specific details of the incident.
The lingering fear of a false alarm and the concern for Tomori made the tone of this caring sentence inevitably urgent. Taki took a few steps to Tomori's side.
What are you looking for? I'll help you find it, and we can go back earlier.
Ah... it's this, I've already found it.
Tomori opened her loosely clenched fist, and two light yellow insects lay quietly in her hand with their bellies facing up.
Although she was already used to Tomori's special fondness for small insects, seeing two bugs at such a close distance still made Taki shudder.
Is this... a cicada?
Yeah. The publisher is doing a series of children's fairy tales on the theme of insects, and they want a fairy tale about cicadas.
I've thought about it for a long time and only came up with a rough idea. I'm still not sure about the specific plot.
Tomori flipped the two small bugs in her palm, and Taki saw the broken gaps on their backs.
(So they're just cicada shells?)
Cicadas are animals of summer. They break out of the ground, reproduce, and die in summer. Their whole life belongs to summer.
I wonder if they would be curious about seasons they've never seen? If they saw winter, what would they think?
It feels like a story very much in Tomori's style.
But now the story is a bit difficult to move forward, and I couldn't write a few paragraphs even after sitting for most of the afternoon.
I thought maybe seeing real cicadas might spark some inspiration.

But summer has passed for a long time. There might still be cicada shells on the trees now, but probably only in the park. However, the parks in the city have patrolling administrators, and digging in the soil in such places would be troublesome...
The other places I'm more familiar with... are only near Taki's house.
I see...
Taki felt the urge to sigh. Tomori's mobility now has made considerable progress compared to when she first met her. Sometimes it even makes her feel overwhelmed.
Did you go out as soon as you thought of this?
If I can't find it here, maybe I can try the woods to the south...
I mean, there's been a lot of rain lately, and even if you were in a hurry to come out, you should have brought an umbrella.
As if to confirm her words, a crackling sound came from the leaves overhead.
Oh no...
Taki took out her phone and started tapping on the screen.
This rain really comes when it says it will. Luckily, there are taxi drivers nearby who are taking orders. Tomori, stay close to me.
Okay.
The streetlights gradually lit up, and the rain gradually increased, making a series of dull sounds, from far to near, on the hood of the taxi.
The two left the shelter of the trees and walked onto the road. Taki opened the back door, and Tomori consciously shrunk into the deep seat, watching Taki close the door again.
Thank you, Taki.
Is this address correct?
Yes, please take her to the door.
Taki nodded, and the car door clicked shut, the whole car trembling slightly.
Remember to send me a text message after you get home!
Okay!

The roar of the taxi sounded, and Tomori leaned half her head out of the car window and waved goodbye to her. So she also stood there and waved, until that purplish-gray hair became a small dot and disappeared at the bend of the cement road that was also soaked into a dark color by the rain.
What an unexpected encounter...
She wanted to sigh something, but the rain was already not allowing her to stand here so leisurely.
I'll think about it after I get home quickly.
